part.narration: Yuki bumps into something in the apartment.
part.line: Oof!
Daughter, watch where you go.
part.narration: The television is on. Jacques and JJ are gathered around it, Jacques glaring. JJ reads a book. Jacques looks at him and sighs.To entice the player to move closer to the television, the camera will focus on it. There are delays in dialogue that end upon moving closer to the pinpointed location; the closer Yuki gets, the more the newscaster speaks. This is known as the TV effect.
part.line: If you really care so much, Yuki, you should be watching.
part.narration: Jacques glares at JJ. JJ does not react. The news programme continues.
part.line: ...as ordered by the Minister of Culture,
the Software Identity Act, the law placing an eight-year wait on the export of French-made software,
as well as the import of foreign-made software, such as operating systems,
media editors and viewers,
system utilities,
production applications,
source code under any license,
and computer games —
part.narration: Jacques sulks. Yuki frowns. JJ continues reading.
part.line: has been passed.
The law has elicited the largest strike ever initiated by France's software industry.
Every step of the law's inception has been opposed by major industry figures.
part.narration: On television, Cuisset appears among cameras and microphones.
part.line: So they blocked us from sharing software with other countries.
What's next? They block us from sharing files with each other?
Many works distributed to France are produced outside.
Many works produced in France are distributed outside.
We are being forced to adapt to legislation with little foresight,
and there are few ways to adapt short of growing wings.
The government will regret this.
The airlines will not.
Cuisset plans to find work in other countries so long as the law is in effect.
Chahi, however, plans to leave the field of software development altogether,
the first spark in the technological collapse that many now refer to as Jan 97.
That's our cue!
What?
part.narration: Yuki raises from her seat. Jacques follows suit, and smirks.
part.line: Time to leave!
So long as that law stands, I won't write a line of code in France.
Therefore, our only option is —
part.narration: Jacques pulls out a world map.Silent sudden cut to a room with an unfittingly large world map.
part.line: migration!
What are you talking about?
We're moving.
We'll have to go somewhere where the IT scene is incredibly prosperous.
part.narration: Jacques points at an indescript location in North America. A dialogue box creeps up.
part.line: Somewhere where the developer is unbound by frivolous law!
part.narration: Jacques points at an indescript location in Europe.

choice.line: We're trying to avoid frivolous law, remember?

part.line: For our predicament, we're moving to the most magical and beneficial place:

narration.comment: Drum roll. The camera slowly zooms in on Australia. One second delay. Jet camera to East Asia.

part.line: We're moving to —

narration.comment: Yuki inhales sharply. Two empty dialog boxes pop up. Before the player can select them, they are pushed out of the way.

part.line: Japan!

narration.comment: Zoom out from the map, to a view of a new, strange, Japanese room.
